text.front:
A Super Camassa–Holm Equation with N-Peakon
Solutions
By Xianguo Geng, Bo Xue, and Lihua Wu
A super Camassa–Holm equation with peakon solutions is proposed, which is
associated with a 3 × 3 matrix spectral problem with two potentials. With
the aid of the zero-curvature equation, we derive a hierarchy of super Harry
Dym type equations and establish their Hamiltonian structures. It is shown
that the super Camassa–Holm equation is exactly a negative flow in the
hierarchy and admits exact solutions with N peakons. As an example, exact
1-peakon solutions of the super Camassa–Holm equation are given. Infinitely
many conserved quantities of the super Camassa–Holm equation and the super
Harry Dym type equation are, respectively, obtained.
text.body:
1. Introduction
Since the discovery of the Camassa–Holm (CH) equation [1]
m t + qm x + 2q x m = 0, m = q − q x x + κ,
(1)
which models unidirectional propagation of long waves in shallow water
and finite length, small amplitude radial deformation waves in cylindrical
hyperelastic rods [2], it has excited much interest in the fields of mathematics
and physics [2–6]. The CH equation has been extensively discussed in a
large number of papers: bi-Hamiltonian structures of the CH equation are
studied, for instance, by Fokas and Fuchssteiner [7], Lorenzoni and Pedroni [8];
scattering and inverse scattering problems for the CH equation are considered
text.front:
Address for correspondence: Bo Xue, Department of Mathematics, Zhengzhou University, 100 Kexue
Road, Zhengzhou, Henan 450001, People' s Republic of China; e-mail: xuebo@zzu.edu.cn
DOI: 10.1111/j.1467-9590.2012.00555.x
1
STUDIES IN APPLIED MATHEMATICS 130:1–16
C
2012 by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology
text.body:
by Constantin [9], Constantin et al. [10]; different kinds of solutions are
discussed by Cooper and Shepard [11], Boyd [12], Beals et al. [13, 14],
Johnson [15], Gesztesy and Holden [16, 17], Li and Zhang [18], Matsuno
[19], Parker and Matsuno [20], Parker [21]. The consequence of such study
is that the CH equation not only shares most of the important properties of
an integrable system of Korteweg-de Vries (KdV) type, but also in the case
κ = 0, it possesses peaked soliton solutions [13, 14, 20–24] which are also
named peakons and have been of great research interest [25–31]. Nowadays,
the CH equation is one of the most studied examples of integrable PDEs.
During the past three decades, the super extension of the classical integrable
systems has received considerable attention because there exists the relation
between the Hamiltonian structures of a super system and super conformal
algebras, and the problem is in itself interesting. In the super system theories,
the anticommuting fields of the Grassmann algebra are equally treated with
the commuting fields. It is found that super equations can be applied to a
variety of problems such as relativistic, nonrelativistic physics, and nuclear
physics [32–55]. A number of famous integrable systems have been embedded
in the super cases, for examples, the super KdV [33, 34] which is relevant
in the study of supersymmetric two-dimensional quantum gravity [35, 36],
super KP [37] which has been found to be of direct relevance for random
matrix models of nonperturbative superstring theory [35, 38], super AKNS
[39, 40], super sine-Gordon [41], super nonlinear Schrödinger [42], super
Harry Dym type equations [43, 44], super Camassa–Holm equation [45–49],
and super Toda lattice hierarchy [50], etc. Various systematic methods in the
classical integrable systems have been developed to obtain exact solutions of
the super integrable systems such as the inverse scattering transformation [41],
the bilinear transformation of Hirota [51–53], the Bäcklund and Darboux
transformations [41, 54, 55], by which some explicit solutions are found.
In this paper, we propose a super CH equation
u t = −(∂u + u∂)w, 2α t = uσ x − (α∂ + 2∂α)w
(2)

introduce a 3 × 3 matrix spectral problem with two potentials, from which a
hierarchy of super Harry Dym type equations is derived. The first typical
member in the hierarchy is

text.note: A Super Camassa–Holm Equation with N-Peakon Solutions
text.body:
The Hamiltonian structures for the hierarchy are constructed by using the
supertrace identity. It is shown that the super CH equation (2) is exactly a
negative flow in the hierarchy and admits N -peakon solutions of the form
σ (x, t) =
N
j=1
σ j (t)e
−
1

,

1

(4)
where σ j , w j ,and x j evolveaccordingtoasuperdynamicalsystem.Moreover,the
infinite sequences of conserved quantities of the super CH equation (2) and
the super Harry Dym type equation (3) are obtained.
Next we briefly describe the structure of this paper. In Section 2, a 3 × 3
matrix spectral problem with two potentials, one is boson and the other is
fermion, is introduced. Resorting to the stationary zero-curvature equation and
Lenard recursion equation, we lead a hierarchy of super Harry Dym type
equations and establish their Hamiltonian structures. In Section 3, we present
a Lax pair of the super CH equation and prove that it is just a negative
flow in the hierarchy given in Section 2. Then the N -peakon solutions of
the super CH equation and the satisfied super dynamical system are obtained
with the help of the distribution approach. As an illustrative example, exact
1-peakon solutions of the super Camassa–Holm equation are obtained. Finally,
in Section 4, infinite many conserved quantities of the super CH equation and
the super Harry Dym type equation are constructed as a direct consequence of
the spectral parameter expansions.
2. Super Harry Dym type equations
In this section, we shall derive a hierarchy of super Harry Dym type equations
and establish their Hamiltonian structures. First, we introduce a 3 × 3 matrix
spectral problem

3. Super Camassa–Holm equation
In this section, we shall derive the super CH equation and prove that it has
N -peakon solutions. Assume φ satisfies the spectral problem (5) and the

4. Conservation laws
In this section, we shall derive infinitely many conservation laws of the super
CH equation (2) and the super Harry Dym type equation (3), respectively. To
this end, we introduce the variables

(57)
5. Conclusion
In this paper, we first extend the CH equation to the super integrable case with
peakon solutions. We present a super CH equation and derive its zero-curvature
representation and infinitely many conserved quantities. It is shown that the
super CH equation shares the standard properties of the CH equation, that is,
the super CH equation is not only completely integrable, but also possesses
N -peakon solutions. Based on the introduced 3 × 3 matrix spectral problem,
we propose a hierarchy of super Harry Dym type equations and obtain their
Hamiltonian structures. It is found that the super CH equation is exactly a
negative flow of this hierarchy, and the super Harry Dym type equation is

in itself interesting and is also reduced to the Harry Dym type equation.
Infinite many conserved quantities of the super Harry Dym type equation are
constructed with aid of the spectral parameter expansions. In respect of the
super CH equation and super Harry Dym type equation what we know is less.
It remains an open question whether they have soliton solutions, Bäcklund
transformations, and other properties, which will be left to a future discussion.
text.div:
Acknowledgment
This work was supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China
(projects no. 11171312 and no. 11126308).
text.listBibl:
References
1. R. CAMASSA and D. D. HOLM, An integrable shallow water equation with peaked
solitons, Phys. Rev. Lett. 71:1661–1664 (1993).
2. H. H. DAI, Model equations for nonlinear dispersive waves in compressible Mooney-Rivlin
rod, Acta Mech. 127:193–207 (1998).
3. R. CAMASSA, D. D. Holm, and J. M. Hyman, A new integrable shallow water equation,
Adv. Appl. Mech. 31:1–33 (1994).
4. B. FUCHSSTEINER and A. FOKAS, Symplectic structures, their Bäcklund transformation
and hereditary symmetries, Physica D 4:47–66 (1981).
5. A. S. FOKAS and Q. M. LIU, Asymptotic integrability of water waves, Phys. Rev. Lett.
77:2347–2351 (1996).
6. H. R. DULLIN, G. A. GOTTWALD, and D. D. HOLM, An integrable shallow water equation
with linear and nonlinear dispersion, Phys. Rev. Lett. 87:194501 (2001).
7. A. S. FOKAS and B. FUCHSSTEINER, On the structure of symplectic operators and
hereditary symmetries, Lett. Nuovo Cimento 28:299–303 (1980).
8. P. LORENZONI and M. PEDRONI, On the bi-Hamiltonian structures of the Camassa-Holm
and Harry Dym equations, Int. Math. Res. Not. 75:4019–4029 (2004).
9. A. CONSTANTIN, On the scattering problem for the Camassa-Holm equation, Proc. R.
Soc. Lond. A 457:953–970 (2001).
10. A. CONSTANTIN, V. S. GERDJIKOV, and R. I. IVANOV, Inverse scattering transform for the
Camassa-Holm equation, Inverse Probl. 22:2197–2207 (2006).
11. F. COOPER and H. SHEPARD, Solitons in the Camassa-Holm shallow water equation,
Phys. Lett. A 194:246–250 (1994).
12. J. P. BOYD, Peakons and coshoidal waves: Travelling wave solutions of the Camassa-Holm
equation, Appl. Math. Comput. 81:173–187 (1997).
13. R. BEALS, D. H. SATINGER, and J. SZMIGIELSKI, Multipeakons and a theorem of Stieltjes,
Inverse Probl. 15:L1-L4 (1999).
14. R. BEALS, D. H. SATINGER, and J. SZMIGIELSKI, Multipeakons and the classical moment
